) This chapter discusses the role of the Central Reconsideration Unit (CRU). The CRU works reconsideration cases for individual income tax returns ously worked by the Area Office or Campus Examination function. (
) The following requests are not considered audit reconsideration cases for purposes and should be routed to the proper functions. a. The audit was for any tax form other than Form

b. If training has not been provided to Campus Correspondence/CRU examiners for the reconsideration issue. These cases will be sent to AO. c. The request is for a fully paid prior audit. This is a Formal Claim for refund. See IRM
, Claims. d. The request is a math error protest. See IRM
, General Math Procedures Overview. e. ASFR, AUR or Appeals assessments. Follow routing procedures under IRM
, Function Responsible & Routing Instructions, for Contact Employees. f. Request for explanation of account balance. g. Refund inquiries. (

) The Taxpayer Advocate Service (TAS) is an independent organization the IRS. TAS helps taxpayers whose problems with the IRS are causing financial difficulties; who have tried but haven’t been able to resolve their problems with the IRS; and those who believe an IRS system or procedure isn’t working as it should. TAS uses the Operations Assistance Request process to refer cases that lack either the statutory or delegated authority resolve. TAS utilizes Form
, Operations Assistance Request, to the OAR process. The Exam TAS liaison will assign and monitor the case through its conclusion. (
) When you receive an OAR you must: a. Contact the Taxpayer Advocate employee listed on the OAR within
day of receipt for TAS cases requiring expedite processing or within

days for all other cases. The OAR will list the Taxpayer Advocate and indicate whether the case requires expedite processing. Note: All TAS cases should be worked as a priority. For specific timeframes for case completion, see the SLA online at: http://tas.web.irs.gov/policy/sla/ default.aspx b. OARs for examinations conducted in the AO will be worked in the campus that is aligned to the AO that did the initial examination. If the campus examiners have not received training for the audit recon issue, the OAR will be forwarded by TAS to the appropriate AO. (
) Supporting documents (if available) that must be attached to Form

when TAS forwards a case are as follows: a. All pertinent information received from the taxpayer. b. Information not considered during the original audit. c. Copies of letters and reports received by the taxpayer. d. Copies of documents already submitted by the taxpayer. e. Amended return, if applicable. Internal Revenue Manual

Audit Note: The administrative file should not be requested. If you need the istrative file, contact TAS to secure the file. (
) Do not contact the taxpayer. TAS will make any and all contacts with the taxpayer. Every effort must be made to expedite completion of OAR cases. (
) When TAS receives a hardship request, they follow all the procedures necessary to verify the taxpayer meets hardship requirements; therefore the CRU should not revalidate the hardship. (

) Review the TAS recommendations and accompanying documentation, and: a. If you agree with the recommendations, contact TAS and inform TAS of your determination, complete the OAR and return to TAS. Work the case to completion. b. If you do not agree with the recommendations, contact TAS and your position, and attempt to reach a mutual determination. If you are unable to come to an agreement with TAS, then the case must be elevated to your manager. TAS and Examination managers are respon- sible for the final resolution. Suspend the case, and provide management with all pertinent information necessary to make a determination. A deter- mination will be reached within
business days, at that time; the will be informed on how to close the case. If agreement on the resolution cannot be reached within

business days, both managers will elevate the issue through the appropriate management channels within TAS and the Operating Division for resolution or the issuance of a Taxpayer Assistance Order. All TAS cases must be worked in adherence with the Service Level (SLA) and addendum between W & I, SB/SE, and TAS. (

4.13.3.13 (12-17-2015) Statute of Limitations

a. Often, an audit reconsideration request is requesting abatement of tax. The taxpayer has made no prior payments towards the liability. Any abatement that the IRS allows will lower or eliminate the balance due, rather than generate a refund. In that case, the Refund Statute of Limita

tions should not be a barrier to allowing the reconsideration or abating tax based on the information the taxpayer submits. b. In cases where the taxpayer has made prior payments and is asking for a tax decrease that could result in an overpayment, the examiner will have to determine if the taxpayer is entitled to receive a refund of that overpay
ment based on the statute of limitations. The statute of limitations that

Audit applies to overpayments is known as the Refund Statute Expiration Date (RSED). Generally, a claim for refund must be filed within three years the time the original return was filed or two years from the time the tax was paid. There may be multiple RSEDs that apply to a taxpayer’s situation, depending on the dates the taxpayer made each payment. c. In the case of a delinquent return the refund statute is the later of three years from the date the return was filed or extended due date or two from the date of the payment(s). Prepaid credits such as the Federal Income tax withholding, Earned Income Credit or the refundable Child Credit are considered paid on the due date of the tax return. d. If the examiner determines that any portion of an overpayment may be barred because of an expired statute of limitation the examiner is to have that excess credit applied to the Excess Collections File (XSF). (

(1) Overview
IRC
(k) allows the IRS to prohibit a taxpayer from claiming EITC for a period of time if the IRS determines that the taxpayer intentionally or recklessly disregarded the rules for claiming EITC (
year ban) or fraudulently claimed EITC (
year ban). When the
or

year ban is applied to a tax year, the taxpayer is notified that the ban is being asserted no later than the Statutory Notice process. The letter must advise the taxpayer of the ban and describe the taxpayer’s conduct giving rise to the ban in the determination year. The original case file must also document mana- gerial approval to impose the ban prior to Statutory Notice of Deficiency issuance per IRM
, Proper Managerial Involvement. IMFOLE and ENMOD will carry

an EITC-recertification Indicator “2” (2-year Ban) or “4” (10-year Ban) along with the year the Ban originated and the Ban expires. For additional information see IRM 20.1.5.2.1, Two and Ten Year Bans on Claiming the Earned Income Tax Credit (EITC), IRM 4.19.14.6.1, EITC 2/10 Year Ban - Correspondence Guidelines for Ex- amination Technicians (CET), and IRC 32(k) (1) (B).
Evaluating 2/10 Year Ban Audit Reconsiderations

The taxpayer needs to address the conduct that was cited in the workpapers for the originating year the ban was imposed. In some cases, the taxpayer will request a reconsideration of the denial of the EITC for a year under the ban instead of the originating year. In that situation, send Letter 3338C or Letter 3339C to advise the taxpayer that he/she must address the imposition of the ban on the originating year before the IRS can consider the more current year when EITC was denied because of the ban. The Audit Recon examiner must request the administrative file or secure the CEAS workpaper and statutory notice, if available, to ascertain the taxpayer’s conduct giving rise to the assertion of the ban. A 10-year Ban was imposed; refer reconsideration to the applicable Area Office or Campus that asserted the ban to be

, Fraud Referrals. (cid:

, Area Office considerations prior to sending. (cid:

The examiner may allow or disallow the ban based on the explanation, testimony, and documentation the taxpayer provided and the facts and circumstances docu- mented in the administrative file. The examiner should bear in mind that the IRS must show that the taxpayer was reckless or intentional (for 2-Year Ban) or fraudu- lent (for 10-Year Ban) to maintain the imposition of the ban in the reconsideration process.
No Documentation - 2-Year Ban

If a request for reconsideration of the Ban is received without any documentation, send Letter 3338Cor Letter 3339C, if applicable, and advise the taxpayer that they must provide documentation to show they were not reckless or intentionally disre- garded the EITC rules for the year the Ban was imposed. Cite the taxpayer conduct as documented in the administrative file or the CEAS work paper. Follow proce- dures under IRM 4.13.3.7.1, No Documentation.
